Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Anticoagulation Strategies in HIT-Positive Patients Undergoing Cardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial included patients with HIT requiring CPB

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive either tirofiban with heparin or standard anticoagulation

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy and safety of tirofiban combined with heparin as an alternative anticoagulation strategy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of thrombotic events during and after surgery, measured over a 30-day period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 50 participants were randomised: 25 to the tirofiban with heparin group and 25 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The tirofiban group showed a reduced incidence of thrombotic events (12% vs. 28%, p=0.04).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included bleeding complications, occurring in 16% of the tirofiban group and 20% of the control group.

Funding.evidence: This study was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
